explanation:
OS_SocketBindAddress / OS_SocketListen — Direct callees of OS_SocketBind. Any for-loops (or functions called from within such loops) in these must be inspected because the behaviour of a for-loop body includes called functions.

OS_SocketBindAddress_Impl / OS_SocketListen_Impl — The implementation functions for the above; the actual loop constructs will be here if not in the wrapper. Required to find any for statements and check their three clauses and loop-counter/flag usage.

OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken, OS_ObjectIdRelease, OS_CreateSocketName, OS_printf — Functions that are directly called (per the static call graph) by OS_SocketBindAddress/OS_SocketListen_Impl or their wrappers. They may contain for-loops themselves or modify objects that could be used as loop counters/flags in enclosing loops; they therefore must be inspected to determine whether any loops reachable from OS_SocketBind violate the MISRA for-loop constraints.

UT_Stub_RegisterReturnType, UT_Stub_RegisterContextWithMetaData, UT_ExecuteBasicHandler, UT_Stub_GetReturnValuePtr — The unit-test/stub infrastructure functions that appear in the call graph of the callees. These may be invoked (directly or indirectly) from the callee implementations and could contain loops or side-effecting expressions that affect compliance; include them to ensure the full call context is examined.

UT_GetStubEntry, UT_ClearStubEntry, UT_SetHandlerFunction, UT_DefaultStubImpl, UtAssert_Abort, UtAssert_GetContext — Lower-level helpers used by the UT_* stubs. Because the MISRA rule requires analyzing the behaviour of functions called from loop bodies transitively, these helper stubs must be available for inspection in case they are invoked by the stub layer and contain for-loops or modify objects used as loop counters/flags.

Note: The list is the minimal set of additional symbols (direct callees, their impls, and the testing/stub helpers present in the static call graph) required to reliably determine whether any for-loop reachable from OS_SocketBind (including loops inside called functions) violates the described MISRA C for-loop constraints.
